NATIONAL NEWS






Avista to test system for harnessing solar rays: CarouSol units use mirrors to focus sunlight onto small cells



Jun. 12--Avista Utilities and a startup San Francisco company plan to test a new solar power system in North Idaho that could provide an electricity boost to help relieve peak summertime energy use.  GreenVolts Inc. will try out its utility-scale, sun-tracking solar array, billed as more cost-effective than traditional models, near an Avista substation in Rathdrum.


Jun 12, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Power plant takes another step forward: State energy officials visit Victorville to get a feel for the project



Jun. 12--VICTORVILLE -- When it comes to a new power plant north of the city, California Energy Commission officials are most concerned with air and water quality.  About a dozen CEC officials launched their decision-making process on Friday to license the plant by coming to Victorville for a site tour and the first of many meetings and hearings. "Air quality is always a big issue," said Gary ...


Jun 12, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Energy aid could be coming to poor families statewide



Jun. 11--The Michigan Public Service Commission has issued two requests for a proposal to provide energy assistance to low-income families across the state. The state utility regulator said up to $50 million could be made available for energy assistance grants and as much as $20 million for energy efficiency grants. The energy efficiency fund was created in 2000 to provide shut-off and other ...


Jun 11, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Proposal could cut utility tax bite nearly in half: Legislative committee backs rate amendment



Jun. 12--The double-barreled tax bite facing We Energies customers as a result of the $1 billion sale of Point Beach nuclear power plant would be cut nearly in half under a proposal before the state Legislature.  A provision of the plant sale calls for We Energies customers to pay a gross receipts tax that's twice as big as the tax now being charged on the sale of electricity generated by the ...


Jun 12, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



TVA names head of fossil operations



Jun. 12--For the second time in the past decade, the Tennessee Valley Authority has tapped one of its top nuclear power executives to direct the utility's 11 coal-fired power plants.  Preston Swafford, a former Exelon Corp. executive who temporarily served as TVA's chief nuclear officer this spring, will succeed Joseph Bynum as executive vice president of TVA's fossil power group. Mr.

Clovis joins utility authority: Competition may spur PG&E to cut electricity rates, mayor says.



Jun. 12--Clovis has become the largest community to join a program that could lead to a local power authority to generate electricity for several Valley communities.  Clovis City Council members approved the plan Monday night despite concerns from Pacific Gas & Electric Co., the existing electricity generation provider, that the promised rates could not be met.

Power still out for 900 Auburn residents



Jun. 12--Approximately 900 Auburn residents are still without power after last nights thunderstorm swept through east Alabama.  Jan Ellis with Alabama Power said the electricity for those customers should be back on between 1 and 2 p.m. Many residents lost their power between 10:30 and 11 p.m., but around 2 a.m. the substation at Barron's Crossroads was lost, which initially affected about 5,000 ...

Jun. 12--ATHENS -- To protect the Tennessee Valley Authority and its distributors from the federal government, area electric departments are trying to form a cooperative.  Athens Electric Department Manager Gary Scroggins told city leaders Monday that TVA owns all transmission and generation assets. "If the federal government decided to sell off TVA, the assets would go in the treasury and our ...

Niles electric bills to rise $4.20/month



City Council agrees to pay I&M actual cost of service. LOU MUMFORD Tribune Staff Writer NILES -- It's called a 'true-up,'' and it will cost customers of the Niles Utilities Department an extra 9 percent on their electric bills. The hike, approved Monday night by the Niles City Council, will amount to an additional $4.20 a month for the average residential user.

'Voluntary' changes for power companies



The Government has backed away from regulating electricity retailers in the wake of the Muliaga case, but is threatening stronger action if beefed up requirements are not met. Prime Minister Helen Clark yesterday said retailers would be subject to new guidelines in dealing with consumers who were struggling to pay their bills or faced disconnection. The guidelines would be voluntary in the ...

The Future of Natural Gas Storage is Here, as Dominion Announces Storage Factory Project

The US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission told the PJM Interconnection Monday to get more specific about its method to determine the economic benefits of a proposed transmission project. Oil slips below $66



LONDON (Reuters) -- Oil slid Tuesday as concerns about inflation and higher borrowing costs dominated financial markets and energy investors focused on increasing shipments of North Sea crude and improving U.S. gasoline stocks.
